header.title: :Volsungadrekka: The Dragon and the Awakened Psyche

central_thesis: This work presents a Left Hand Path system rooted in Germanic/Norse mythology, particularly the Sigurd mythos and Dragon symbolism, to facilitate the 'Awakened Psyche' and 'Remanifestation.' It guides the initiate through conscious application of a 'nine-fold pattern' (the Order's symbol) to dismantle the physical and metaphysical aspects of the psychosomatic complex, ultimately achieving 'Isolate Intelligence' and the 'omnijective perspective' of the Dragon. The text explicitly serves the reconstitution and objectives of the Order of Apep.

structure_content.summary: Defines 'Volsungadrekka' as a kenning for 'Dragon's Venomous Blood,' symbolizing an awakened psyche. It outlines the book's purpose: to reconstitute the Order of Apep by exploring the Germanic Dragon, its relation to time, soul, and transformation, using the Drachenknut as a personal symbol in 'workings' to focus on the 'patron egregore.' The author emphasizes a focus on Germanic traditions, avoiding external comparisons.

Contrasts linear modern time with the non-linear Germanic view, essential for 'heretical' Left Hand Path transformational magic and 'The Black Flame.' It introduces the three Norns of time: Urdhr (Ideal Reality/Past), Skuld (Non-Past/Conditioned by Ideal), and Verdandi (Moment of Absolute Freedom/Present), illustrating this through the Valknutr. This chapter also explores concepts of 'Ginnung' (void of illusion) and 'Ve' (sacred space/wihaz as a state of being), linking the cultivation of inner sacred space to connecting with the 'Fylgja' (following spirit).

structure_content.chapter_title: III. The Dragon and the Dead
structure_content.summary: Examines the Dragon's association with the dead in Germanic folklore, drawing on H.R. Ellis Davidson and Beowulf. The Dragon is presented as a guardian of burial mounds and a catalyst for transformation, with Nidhoggr in the Voluspa devouring death to facilitate new life. The concept of 'aptrborinn' (remanifestation) in heroic cultures, exemplified by Sigurd, is highlighted as a form of reincarnation of soul attributes, linking the Dragon to the overcoming of death.

structure_content.chapter_title: IV. The Scaly Skin of the Awakened Psyche
structure_content.summary: Focuses on the Dragon's role as a 'destroyer of the physical and some metaphysical aspects of the psychosomatic complex,' leading to the 'immortalisation of the Hero' and 'Isolate Intelligence.' It delves into Germanic soul lore (Ond, Odr, Lik, Hugr, Minni), 'Hamr' (shape-shifting substance), 'Hamingja' (metaphysical luck), and 'Sal' (the shadow self, identified as the Dragon's Lair). The Fylgja, or fetch spirit, is emphasized as crucial for the initiate's experience, while noting subjective and regional interpretations of serpent/dragon dreams.

Discusses Old Norse terms 'Blod' (blood) and 'sveiti' (venom), presenting the Dragon's blood as inherently venomous and transformative. The Sigurd myth is used to illustrate how consuming or contacting this blood grants occult understanding. The chapter connects these concepts to ancient earthworks, barrows, and hill forts as 'Dragon power contained within' and ideal sites for 'Grand Initiation,' drawing parallels to Beowulf and Viking practices of adorning ships with dragon heads for protection and terror.

Identifies the 'heart' of the Germanic Dragon with the 'nine-fold articulation of RUNA.' It introduces Stephen E. Flowers' 'Magus Word' RUNA as the 'objectification of the ultimate subject,' aiming for an 'omnijective perspective'—an 'icy, distant and detached reptilian view.' This chapter elaborates on three perspectives: Subjective (Belief/Trust, Seeing/Hearing), Objective (Understanding, Knowing/Doing), and Omnijective (Conscious Awakening, Thought/Memory/Hrafnmal), explaining how Sigurd's journey, culminating in tasting Fafnir's blood, leads to this profound awareness and self-realization (Ryna, Raena, Raun).

Describes the Dragon's Lair in Nifleheim, an icy realm of stasis containing Hvergelmir, the 'roaring cauldron' of creative potential. Nidhoggr, the 'Dread Biter,' gnaws at Yggdrasill's roots at Hvergelmir, promoting 'vigorous growth' through its function as a devourer of the dead and unused ideas, thereby facilitating rejuvenation/remanifestation. It distinguishes Nidhoggr from Loki's brood, emphasizing its primordial and pre-existing nature, and explores Jordmungandr (World Serpent) as a 'Great Magical Staff' representing the temporal cosmos and Draconis as the guardian of the Pole.

Serves as a conclusion, quoting Nikolas Schreck from the Order of Apep Elist: 'The Dragon will only yield its secrets to those that have played the game by the rules.' This reinforces that the path, explicitly identified as Left Hand Path, demands 'values and personal ethics or authority,' indicating an ongoing, lifelong 'LIFE's work' of self-transformation and initiation.

Provides a comprehensive list of primary and secondary sources, categorized by chapter, essential for further study into Germanic magic, Runology, and the esoteric themes presented. Notable authors include Paul C. Bauschatz, Don Webb, Guido von List, Edred Thorsson, H.R. Ellis Davidson, S.E. Flowers, William Morris, and Snorri Sturluson, highlighting the academic and practical foundations of the work.

key_concepts.definition: An Old Norse kenning for 'Dragon's Venomous Blood,' symbolizing an awakened psyche and the ability to comprehend esoteric truths, akin to Sigurd understanding the speech of birds after tasting Fafnir's blood.
A state of heightened consciousness and perception, the result of initiatory processes and a deep understanding of the psychosomatic complex, enabling 'Isolate Intelligence' and 'Remanifestation.'
A magical order that the author is actively working to reconstitute. The entire book is framed as a foundational document and guide for its members and their esoteric objectives.
A personal symbolic tool utilized by the author in magical 'workings' to focus on the 'patron egregore' of the Order, representing the initiate's quest and commitment.

A non-linear perception of time, contrasted with modern linear views, foundational for Left Hand Path transformational magic. It is conceptualized through the Norns: Urdhr (Ideal Reality/Past), Skuld (Non-Past/Conditioned by Ideal), and Verdandi (Moment of Absolute Freedom/Present), often illustrated by the Valknutr.

A 'heretical process of non-linear activity of transformational magic' involving the 'application of consciousness,' referred to as 'The Black Flame,' aiming for profound self-transformation and the attainment of higher states of being outside conventional spiritual linearity.

An Old Norse term referring to both 'sacred space' and a specific 'state of being.' Entering this state deeply during ritual workings is intended to contradict ordinary perceptions of Time and Space, potentially inducing 'sheer terror' and fostering a connection with the 'Fylgja.'

A 'following spirit' that serves as a magical link between the phenomenal and numinous realms, experienced by the individual. It can manifest in animal, contra-sexual, or symbolic forms (e.g., Valkyrie), and is of 'utmost importance' for the initiate.

The 'shadow self,' conceptualized as the 'realm of past ideas not used or dead.' This is explicitly identified as 'The Dragon's Lair' and the dwelling place of Nidhoggr and the well Hvergelmir, indicating its role in dissolution and regeneration.

The 'ultimate Rune' and the 'nine-fold articulation' in Old Norse. It represents 'the objectification or objectifying of the ultimate subject,' which, when attained, leads to the 'omnijective perspective.' Esoteric Rune knowledge is fundamental to the system.

The ultimate state of consciousness sought, characterized as an 'icy, distant and detached reptilian view.' It is an absolute consciousness, achieved by balancing thought and memory ('Hrafnmal') and integrating subjective and objective realities, enabling a profound understanding of life's mysteries ('Ryna').

A primordial Dragon at Hvergelmir, gnawing at the roots of Yggdrasill. Its function is the 'devourer of the dead'—meaning dead ideas within the initiate's psyche and uninitiated souls—thereby performing a 'primary function of rejuvenation or remanifestation' through dissolution and creation.

The 'roaring cauldron' or wellspring located in Nifleheim, an icy realm of stasis. It is described as boiling with 'potential of creation' and is the source of all rivers, where Nidhoggr resides, facilitating the cyclical processes of destruction and renewal.

Beyond specific mythological figures, the Dragon represents the 'destroyer of the physical and some metaphysical aspects of the psychosomatic complex,' a fetch animal, a symbol of powerful insight, and an agent of immortalization and 'omnijective perspective.' Its blood and essence are central to awakening the psyche.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined is a Left Hand Path approach to 'conscious awakening' and 'remanifestation,' leveraging Germanic Dragon lore and the Sigurd myth. It involves the initiate consciously applying a 'nine-fold pattern' (the Order's symbol) to dismantle the 'psychosomatic complex' and achieve 'Isolate Intelligence.' This includes cultivating an inner 'sacred space' (wihaz), engaging with fetch spirits (fylgja), and undertaking 'workings' to attain the Dragon's 'omnijective perspective.' The process integrates intellectual understanding (Knowing), active engagement (Doing), and the balancing of thought and memory (Hrafnmal) to uncover life's mysteries (Ryna).
tools: The Drachenknut (a personal symbol for the initiate's quest and magical workings).
Magical landscapes, such as hill forts, barrows, and ancient earthworks, utilized as ideal outdoor working areas.
Runes, both exoteric for intellectual comprehension and esoteric for operative application and self-understanding.
The 'nine-fold pattern' or Order symbol, used as a focal point for conscious application in transformational work.
Traditional texts (Eddas, Sagas) and specific magical/esoteric works (e.g., S.E. Flowers' 'Magus Word' RUNA) for guidance and deeper insight.
The 'sword,' symbolic of manhood, nobility, and potentially containing the Dragon/Serpent's spirit through its patterned construction.
rituals: Conducting 'workings' for the reconstitution of the Order of Apep and focusing on its 'patron egregore.'
Performing 'Grand Initiation' rituals, possibly in sites like ancient hill forts or earthworks, that align with the descriptions of Dragon lairs.
Conscious application of the 'nine-fold pattern' as an operative magical act for initiation and self-transformation.
Entering the 'wihaz' (sacred state of being) to effect transformation by contradicting linear time and space perception.
Developing and experiencing the 'fylgja' as a 'following spirit' through intentional magical practice.
The symbolic act of understanding the Dragon's blood (akin to Sigurd's act) for gaining occult knowledge and conscious awareness.

relevant_quotes.text: Volsungadrekka is an Old Norse term for the drink of the Volsungs, this is a kenning for the Dragon's Venomous Blood. Sigurd drank and was able to understand the speech of birds. This activity is synonymous with an awakened psyche and of interest to the Order of Apep.

Linearity is the procession of steps, stages or phases that follows a set pattern. It is ordered and fixed and therefore does not allow for the heretical process of the non-linear activity of transformational magic known as the Left Hand Path. Such activities are the application of consciousness, The Black Flame.
The ultimate Rune is the objectification or objectifying of the ultimate subject. This would be entry into the ring of RUNA and attainment of the omnijective perspective.
The Dragon will only yield its secrets to those that have played the game by the rules
What I am really saying is that if Fafnir was thought to be a heretic for suggesting reincarnation in the old regime, then they would be setting up the stake and lighting the tinder for me!

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is highly relevant to specialized practitioners of Germanic/Norse esotericism, particularly those aligned with Left Hand Path currents and Dragon mysticism. It offers a unique synthesis of mythic analysis, runology, and operative magical philosophy to articulate a distinct system of self-transformation. Its emphasis on a 'Germanic reptilian current' provides a focused, deep dive into a specific, potent, and often misunderstood aspect of occult tradition.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of members of the Order of Apep, as the book is explicitly 'published exclusively' for them and serves its reconstitution. Beyond this, it targets serious, advanced practitioners of the Left Hand Path, runologists, and scholars/initiates with a strong foundation in Germanic/Norse magical traditions. The text is dense with technical terminology and presupposes a degree of prior knowledge, recommending extensive use of the provided bibliography for full comprehension, indicating it is not for beginners.
